title: What's your favorite humanist typeface?
content:
Hi,

I'm going to be working on a identity redo for an architectural frim that specilizes in planning and urban design. I'm interested in a [humanist](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/humanist) font that's classic, clean, and sturdy enough to be a workmark at different scales - what's your favorite?

Many Thanks
author: JB01

comments.content:
\>PMN Caecilia

How come when you said 'Humanist', I was thinking just of sans? Am I normal?

Usually, humanist does come up in connection with sans-serifs, but it's not so unusual to hear about humanist slab-serifs. Other than PMN Caecilia, the humanist slabs off the top of my head are [TheSerif](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.lucasfonts.com/index_neu.html), Chaparral, and the brand new [Soho](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.linotype.com/3273/soho.html?PHPSESSID=34e1c19945b7c8e50a9d4660378eb6fc). I also can't resist throwing in [Rayuela](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/pampatype.com/php/English/Tipografias_RR.php?secc=cara&menu=menu_T_C.html&sub1=sub1_T_RR_C.html&sub2=sub2_T_R_C.html&pag=pag_T_RR_C.html), which, though not really a slab-serif, does have a distinct humanist quality, greater than that of most non-script typefaces.

Hope these non-sans typefaces could be useful alternatives; I don't mean to hijack the thread. To atone, here's a thread purporting to offer a list of the best humanists sans-serifs: [http://typophile.com/node/13281](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/typophile.com/node/13281 "http://typophile.com/node/13281") . Check the list at the very bottom.
Nick, I think, perhaps, it is because of Humanist 521 from the Bitstream library. I have the same thought pattern I think.

_Am I normal?_  
i doubt it. there's no such thing as "normal."

maybe i have it all wrong, but to me , the term _[humanist](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/humanist)_ refers to letters that are influenced by [ductal logic](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/ductal%2520logic), whether they're [sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/sans%2520serif) or [serifed type](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/serif).  
in [calligraphy](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/calligraphy), the [humanist minuscule](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/humanist%2520minuscule) is a descendant of the [carolingian minuscule](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/carolingian%2520minuscule). The humanist model of calligraphy is what influenced the earliest [Roman](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Roman) ( [whiteletter](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/whiteletter)) types, particularly those of [Nicholas Jenson](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Nicholas%2520Jenson). The [Vox-ATypI classification](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Vox-ATypI%2520classification) system uses the term humanist to refer to the [Venetian](http://web.archive.org/web/20100207003327/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Venetian) model of type.

Doesn't sound wrong to me, Paul. But I rarely see "humanist" bandied about in regard to serifs (with the exception of typefaces inspired by Italian Renaissance type), maybe because many more serifs are "humanist" by your ductal-logic definition than are sans- and slab-serifs. I'd guess that this comes from the early slab-serifs and sans-serifs not being too concerned with ductus as far as I know until Johnston and Gill in the early 20th c. and Frutiger in 1968. So to say "humanist" doesn't separate a group out as much for serifs as it does for other type genres.
Tiff, I'm with you and Nick -- if someone says "humanist," only sans faces spring to my mind.
I am with Paul D. Hunt, and mine is Pastonchi.
It is odd, though, don't you think Linda? I mean I studied the birth of the roman alphabet and yet I still think of a sans type. Silly!

not so silly, i think the humanist/geometric sans distinguisher makes a lot of sense, whereas we usually use other terms to specify humanist serif types: most of us would probably just call them "Venetian."

Not "silly" at all, Tiff! (And don't tell Chris, but the first font that springs to mind when I think "humanist" is Optima! ;-) )

Paul, you're spot on: any idea why some call them one or the other? (That's probably a stupid question, but....)

_any idea why some call them one or the other?_

because we English-speaking folk don't follow the VOX classification system.

That figures -- in the "old days" the English-speaking world didn't "do" metric either. At least here in Canada, the young'uns barely know an inch or a degree Fahrenheit these days.

Time changes things, of course....

No sweat, I won't tell him :-P
